concern:
My university allowed a student religious organization on campus to invite a speaker to host an event. The speaker is outwardly and actively pro-conversion therapy and the vice chancellor states that they can’t do anything because of “freedom of speech” which obviously is something that can’t be infringed upon but this feels like bordering hate speech. I’m non-binary and very gay, and I feel very, very lost. 

I’m not sure what else can be done. Some news outlets I think are picking it up and protests are planned, but I feel kind of helpless. Any more tips for trying to fight this?

Edit to answer some questions: the event is allegedly discussing LGBT issues that our generation is facing. I've looked at some of the speaker's speeches, and her website, and she very clearly talks about sex and gender being the same thing, how that wasn't God's original plan, how we're destroying his "sweet language," that trans people aren't real, how it's all deception... etc. There is an LGBTQIA+ organization on campus, and they're leading the protest with the assistance of some local churches. 

I also realize that I may have used 'hate speech' incorrectly, and I do understand that despite how weird it is, it is protected under the First Amendment.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm here to listen and support you, so feel free to share whatever's on your mind today.

client: Hey, thanks for being here. I'm feeling really overwhelmed right now. There's this speaker coming to campus who's pushing harmful ideas about LGBTQ+ people, and it's just been really hard to deal with.
therapist: It sounds like this situation is really weighing on you. How is this affecting your day-to-day life?
client: It's been tough to concentrate on my studies, and I'm constantly anxious about running into discussions or news about the event. It's just always in the back of my mind, you know?
It seems like this situation is impacting not only your studies but also your peace of mind. What would life look like for you if this weight was lifted off your shoulders?

I think I'd feel a lot more focused and able to enjoy my time on campus without constantly being on edge. I'd be able to concentrate on my studies and spend time with friends without this constant worry hanging over me.
It sounds like having more focus and peace would be really meaningful for you. What steps do you think might bring you closer to feeling that way, even with the situation still unfolding?

Honestly, I've been thinking about trying to focus more on the support around me, like spending time with friends or maybe getting more involved with the LGBTQIA+ organization on campus. I've also thought about using some mindfulness techniques we talked about to help manage my anxiety.

It sounds like you're considering a few supportive strategies, like connecting with friends and engaging with the LGBTQIA+ organization, as well as using mindfulness techniques. Based on what you said, possible options include setting aside specific times each week for these activities or starting with a small daily mindfulness practice. How do these ideas align with what you're thinking, and what might be your first step?

I think those ideas are in line with what I’m hoping to do. Maybe I can start by setting some time to meet with friends this week and pick a few days to practice mindfulness. It feels like a good starting point, you know?

It sounds like you've got a thoughtful plan in place to start easing that weight off your shoulders. By setting aside time to connect with friends and practicing mindfulness, you're taking meaningful steps toward finding that focus and peace you're seeking. Remember, even small actions can lead to significant changes over time. It's encouraging to hear you're aligning your actions with your goals. As you move forward this week, keep in mind that it's okay to take things at your own pace. If you ever need more support, I'm here to help you. You've got this, and I'm confident in your ability to navigate through this challenging situation.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll try to remind myself to take it slow and see how these small steps work out for me.
